Table 1 Structural and elemental properties of different samples. Sample S t (m2/g) V t (cm3/g) r (nm) P25 89.7 0.159 6.5 TiO2 16.8 0.032 6.8 Zr0.05Ti0.95O2 78.6 0.197 8.3 Zr0.1Ti0.9O2 81.6 0.250 10.1 Zr0.15Ti0.85O2 74.0 0.212 9.5 S t: specific surface area; V t: total pore volume; R: pore radius. Photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous HCHO by Zr x Ti1−x O2 catalysts under UV–vis light irradiation with an energy-saving lamp Qiong Huang a Wenjiao Ma a Xiaokang Yan a Yingwen Chen a Shemin Zhu b Shubao Shen a ⁎ a Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Materials – Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing 211816, China b College of Materials Science and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Materials – Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing 211816, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: No. 30 Puzhu South Road, Nanjing University of Technology, Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, 211816 Nanjing, China. Tel.: +86 25 58139922; fax: +86 25 83587326. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Photocatalytic oxidation of gaseous HCHO by Zr x Ti1−x O2 samples under visible-light irradiation was discussed. ► With increasing the hydroxyl groups, the activity of samples of Zr x Ti1−x O2 was increased. ► The result shows that L–H model is valid at the beginning of catalytic oxidation. ► The photocatalytic activitie of Zr0.08Ti0.92O2 samples was affected by the humidity of air. TiO2, a widely used, inexpensive white powder, has been considered the most promising photocatalyst for the degradation of formaldehyde in air. However, the application of TiO2 without other metal and nonmetal doping is limited because it requires UV activation with a high-energy band gap, and <5% of the solar radiation reaching the earth's surface can be used. To improve the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, sol–gel nano TiO2 with Zr doping can be activated by the UV–vis radiation available in sunlight to perform solar photocatalysis. The properties of the Zr x Ti1−x O2 catalysts were fully characterised by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). Our results demonstrate that the optical response of TiO2 was shifted from UV to the visible light region with the introduction of zirconium. The photocatalytic tests indicated that the Zr x Ti1−x O2 catalyst demonstrated higher activity for the degradation of formaldehyde compared with P25 and TiO2 under UV–vis light irradiation with an energy-saving lamp. Keywords Photocatalysts Zr x Ti1−x O2 Formaldehyde UV–vis light Energy-saving lamp 1 Introduction Most people spend as much as 90% of their time indoors; therefore, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), carbonyl compounds and nitrogen oxides (NO x ) released from buildings may pose a greater threat to people's health than those in the outdoor air. In particular, formaldehyde (FAD) has significant harmful effects on human health and may cause some diseases of the respiratory tract and even leukaemia and cancers. To improve indoor air quality (IAQ), steps should quickly be taken to reduce or eliminate formaldehyde [1,2]. An alternative remediation technology, which offers a number of advantages over conventional technologies, is the use of photocatalytic oxidation (PCO) at low or room temperature; PCO can degrade a broad range of formaldehyde species into innocuous final products such as CO2 and H2O without significant energy input. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been widely investigated as a promising catalyst for the removal of formaldehyde since 1970s due to its excellent photocatalytic activity, nontoxicity, high stability against photocorrosion and low cost [3]. When TiO2 is irradiated by light of wavelength (λ)<387nm, electron-hole pairs (e− and h+) are generated in the bulk particle and electrons are promoted across the band gap (3.0 or 3.2eV in the anatase or rutile crystalline phase, respectively) into the conduction band, which leaves holes in the valence band. These holes have high oxidation power and react with adsorbed hydroxide ions to produce hydroxyl radicals, which are the main oxidising species responsible for the photooxidation of formaldehyde. However, the application of pure TiO2 is limited because it requires UV activation, and <5% of the solar radiation reaching the earth's surface can be used. Consequently, considerable effort has been directed towards expanding the optical response of TiO2 from the UV to the visible light region [4]. To improve the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, many studies aimed at modifying TiO2 have been performed, and strategies including doping with metals or nonmetals and compounding TiO2 with other materials (semiconductors or some organic dye) have been proposed [5–8]. Doping with metals or nonmetals was the most feasible method for improving the photocatalytic performance of TiO2. When the electron–hole pairs migrate from the inside of the photocatalysts to the surface, the doping metal atoms can suppress the recombination of photo-induced electron–hole pairs to increase the photo quantum efficiency. At the same time, some doping metal oxides have a low band gap (<3.0eV) that could absorb more visible-light for the photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous HCHO. In the present study, we used a glass-plate photoreactor to investigate the application of TiO2 photocatalyst powder to remove a low concentration of formaldehyde. Additionally, the effects of P25 and the adsorbents of TiO2 were studied and determined. The improved performance of TiO2 doped with ZrO2 over pure TiO2 with UV–vis light was also discussed. Moreover, the Langmuir–Hinshelwood model was used to evaluate the reaction procedures and principle [9]. 2 Experiment 2.1 Photocatalyst preparation In a typical experiment, a certain amount of zirconium oxychloride was dissolved in 21ml of ethanol solution and 1ml of deionised water to form solution A. Under vigorous stirring with 10min to dissolve solid materials completely and the solution B with 6.9ml of tetrabutyl titanate was added drop-wise into the solution A with 7min under vigorous stirring at room temperature to prepare the gel. The mixed gel was aged for 48h and dried for 2h at 80°C. The obtained sample was thoroughly ground with an agate mortar pestle and calcined at 450°C for 2.5h. The catalysts were designated as Zr x Ti1−x O2. For comparison with Zr x Ti1−x O, pure TiO2 was prepared by the same method without zirconium oxychloride. 2.2 Photocatalyst characterisation XRD patterns of the TiO2 photocatalyst powder were recorded using a D/max-RB X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15406nm) in a 2θ range of 5–80°. The scanning speed was 4°/min. The standard diffraction charts of anatase and rutile were used to compare with the resulting XRD patterns. The morphology and particle size of TiO2 in the prepared sample were observed by SEM (JSM-5900, The JEOL of Japan). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of the spent catalysts and pre-treated were determined by nitrogen adsorption at 77K using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 analyser. The UV–vis spectra of samples were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 950 UV–vis spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere attachment. The scanning range was between 250nm and 800nm, and BaSO4 was used as a reference. IR spectra on KBr pellets of the samples were recorded on a Nicolet 410 FT-IR spectrometer at a resolution of 4cm−1. The concentration of the samples in KBr was maintained at approximately 0.3%. 2.3 Degradation The degradation test was performed on a self-designed glass reactor (0.22m3, 600×600×600mm) with a small window, which was connected to PPM-400ST Formaldehyde Metre (PPM Technology Ltd., England) that is designed to measure formaldehyde concentrations from 0 to 24.56mg/m3 in snatch samples of air. A known amount of formaldehyde was injected with a microsyringe into the vessel in the dark and then volatilised in air. The formaldehyde concentration was 1.0±0.5mg/m3 at the beginning of the experiment. A 45W energy-saving lamp provided the UV–vis light source and was located 10cm above the catalysts. A total of 0.4g of Zr x Ti1−x O2 photocatalyst powder was well dispersed through a stainless steel sieve (screen mesh: 100) to form a thin layer on a culture dish; it was then placed at the bottom of the glass reactor. After allowing the formaldehyde on the Zr x Ti1−x O2 photocatalysts to reach a state of adsorption and desorption equilibrium over 48h, the energy-saving lamp was turned on and the formaldehyde concentration was measured every 12h. Degradation experiments were carried out for 4 days. The measurements were repeated three times for each point, and the results were averaged. To investigate the photocatalytic activity of different catalysts, a set of gaseous experiments was carried out at room temperature (25±1°C) under 50±5% humidity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analyses Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the P25, TiO2, and Zr x Ti1−x O2 (with varying weight percentages of Zr doping) catalysts. All samples were calcined in air at 450°C for 2.5h. P25 and pure TiO2 power had a mixed crystal structure of anatase and rutile phases. It was found that the crystalline of TiO2 with Zr doping was weaker than pure TiO2 based on the intensity of the (101) peak [1]. It appeared that the amount of Zr had an effect on the crystallite size of grafted nanosized TiO2, with smaller amounts of Zr resulting in a smaller crystallite size, which may be helpful for enhancing photocatalytic activity. The Zr0.05Ti0.95O2 sample mainly consisted of the anatase phase, with a broad peak approximately 15° corresponding to the monoclinic phase [10]. However, there was no monoclinic phase peak in the other samples. The XRD patterns revealed that doping could prevent enhancement of the TiO2 crystalline. It could also be concluded that Zr doping had an effect on the crystalline and particle size. When compared with pure TiO2, it should be noted that the position of the diffraction angle of the Zr x Ti1−x O2 samples gradually shifts to a lower value as the amount of Zr increases. This change is attributed to the substitution of larger Zr4+ ions (0.087nm) for smaller Ti4+ ions (0.064nm). This phenomenon is most likely due to the existence of Ti–O–Zr in the mixed oxides, which inhibits the growth of anatase crystals by providing dissimilar boundaries. The result correlates well with XPS results. The peaks at 181.6 and 183.9eV were attributed to Zr3d5/2 and Zr3d3/2, respectively. The binding energy of Zr3d5/2 in Zr0.10Ti0.90O2 was different from the single oxides of ZrO2 (179.0eV). The results illustrate that Ti–O–Zr existed in the Zr x Ti1−x O2 samples. 3.2 SEM and BET analyses Fig. 2 shows the surface topography of the Zr0.08Ti0.92O2 powder catalysts. The particles of powder can be observed clearly in Fig. 2(a) and were heterogeneous in size from 0.5 to 50μm. This heterogeneity was caused by inadequate grinding of the powder by hand. However, some spherical-like TiO2 particles were found on the surface of the particulate. The spherical-like particles can be observed more clearly in Fig. 2(b) [11]. The TiO2 crystallite size in the composites was too small to show perfect crystals, and this result was confirmed by the XRD data described above. Increased calcination temperatures or extended time of calcination is therefore required to enhance crystallinity to improve photocatalytic activity of the catalysts. Moreover, without sufficient calcination the catalysts could effectively wipe off the ethanol to affect the PPM-400ST results. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were determined by BET measurements and are summarised in Table 1 . P25 powder showed a high surface area of approximately 89.7m2/g. However, the surface area and pore volume of TiO2 prepared by the experimental method were only 16.8m2/g and 0.031cm3/g, respectively, which were unfavourable for formaldehyde adsorption and catalytic oxidation. On the other hand, the surface area of TiO2 doped with Zr increased significantly when comparing with pure TiO2. This result indicates that Zr doping by the thermal treatment of titania with zirconium oxychloride produced significant changes in the surface area and pore volume of the titania. The effects of Zr doping on pore structure and BET surface areas of the Zr x Ti1−x O2 hollow spheres were investigated by the nitrogen sorption measurement. Fig. 3 shows the nitrogen sorption isotherms of TiO2 and Zr x Ti1−x O2 hollow nanospheres with various Ti:Zr ratios. The isotherm of the pure TiO2 sample is a type IV isotherm with a broad hysteresis loop at relative pressure (P/P 0) between 0.4 and 0.9, indicating the presence of mesopores and macropores. The isotherm that corresponds to the Zr x Ti1−x O2 hollow spheres changes with increasing amounts of ZrO2 doping, especially at relative pressure (P/P 0) between 0.4 and 0.9. The hysteresis loop is type H3, implying the formation of slit-like pores that are generally associated with aggregates of plate-like particles or fractured porous materials. At this range, the isotherm exhibits increasing adsorption with increasing ZrO2 species, suggesting that the mesopores have been increased. Both The increase in both the surface area and pore volume can be attributed to the decomposition of zirconium oxychloride and chemical attack of hydrogen chloride and oxygen, which erodes the titania surface. This erosion may have provided more accessible active sites and improved the catalytic active. 3.3 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy Fig. 4 shows the UV–vis spectra of the typical samples Zr0.05Ti0.95O2, Zr0.08Ti0.92O2, Zr0.1Ti0.9O2, Zr0.12Ti0.88O2, Zr0.15Ti0.85O2 and TiO2. Weak absorption in the visible light region was observed for the samples Zr0.08Ti0.2O2 and Zr0.1Ti0.9O2, which is due to the new energy level or lattice defects observed with Zr doping. Compared with pure TiO2, the TiO2 catalysts with Zr doping demonstrated a stronger adsorption in the UV light and visible light ranges, which was helpful for increasing catalytic activity. In the region, pure TiO2 showed the weakest adsorption with this method of preparation. The results clearly indicated that Zr doping led to a strong adsorption of UV–vis light, which may improve the catalytic activity. 3.4 FT-IR The FT-IR transmittance spectra of TiO2 and Zr0.08Ti0.92O2 powder were determined by the KBr pellet method and are presented in Fig. 5 . A wide absorption band between 400 and 850cm−1 corresponded to Ti–O in the powder. Some broader peaks at 3403cm−1 and a stronger peak at 1634cm−1 were attributed to the O–H stretching vibration of water, hydroxyl groups, and hydrated species on the surface of catalysts, respectively [1,12]. It is well known that the superficial TiO2 hydroxyl group plays an important role in the photocatalytic activity. The difference in peak intensity demonstrated that Zr0.08Ti0.92O2 has a more sufficient hydroxyl group than TiO2 does. 3.5 Photocatalytic activity for formaldehyde degradation Fig. 6 shows the degradation of formaldehyde versus illumination time by different photocatalysts under UV–vis light with an energy-saving lamp. The adsorption behaviour of all these catalysts was determined in the dark for 48h, and the conversions of adsorption were approximately 13±2% [13]. The TiO2 and P25 samples were observed to barely degrade formaldehyde, which is due to the irradiation of TiO2 and P25 with UV light only and the lack of enough of hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface. It was also observed that the Zr x Ti1−x O2 samples exhibited visible light-induced degradation of formaldehyde, and the catalytic activities of these samples were all superior to the P25 and TiO2 samples, indicating the Zr doping could suppress the recombination of photo-produced electron–hole pairs and raise the photo quantum efficiency. Moreover, Zr doping could increase the number of hydroxyl groups and high surface area active sites to enhance the catalytic activity. The percentage of formaldehyde removed with only the 45W light was 92.4%, which is a higher conversion rate than that observed for N–Ni–TiO2 [7] and C–TiO2 [5]. These catalysts with different metal or nonmetal doping showed only approximately 80% conversion after high light intensity. The lowest concentration was remained at approximately 0.15–0.19mg/m3, which was higher than the WHO guideline. It was disadvantageous to the photocatalytic degradation of HCHO in the office or car. The Zr0.08Ti0.92O2 catalyst showed the best photoactivity, and the concentration of formaldehyde was reduced to below 0.08mg/m3 (WHO guideline) at 48h, which is in agreement with the UV–vis DRS, FT-IR and BET results [14]. The results showed that Zr x Ti1−x O2 could increase the catalytic activity by enhancing the hydroxyl groups or UV–vis light-induced degradation. Meanwhile, the photogenerated electrons were transferred from the valence band of TiO2 to the valence band of ZrO2. An efficient transfer separation increased the lifetime of the photo-generated electron and hole. Therefore, the photocatalytic properties increased because the possibility of recombination between the photo-generated electron and hole was reduced by facilitating electron separation [14,15]. In a surface-catalysed reaction, chemisorption is of interest. Langmuir first developed the adsorption isotherm that lead to a unimolecular layer of adsorbed molecules. Hinshelwood then began applying the Langmuir isotherms to various reactants and products, and the developed model was thus called the Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic model. In general, the kinetic model of the PCO process would follow the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H model), in which the reaction rate (r) varies proportionally with the surface coverage (θ) as [16]: r = k θ = k K c 1 + K c where k is the rate constant, K is the adsorption constant and c is the formaldehyde concentration. By substituting the L–H rate expression into the first-order kinetics equation of a fixed reactor, the following expression is obtained: t c 0 − c = 1 k K ln ( c 0 / c ) c 0 − c + 1 k where c 0 is the initial formaldehyde concentration and t is the reaction time. If L–H kinetics are valid for the gas–solid reaction, then a plot of t/(c 0 − c) versus ln(c 0/c)/(c 0 − c) should be linear and can be tested by using different c and t values. The values of k and K can be obtained from the intercept and slope of the line, respectively. The result demonstrates that the L–H model is valid at the beginning of the catalytic reaction; however, when the concentration of formaldehyde is low, formaldehyde adsorption on the surface is the controlling step. To study the effect of relative humidity on HCHO removal, a third set of experiments was performed under various relative humidities (RHs) ranging from 45 to 90%. Fig. 7 shows the experimental results for the degradation of HCHO at different RHs. A RH of 50±5% was shown to achieve the highest activity, and moisture can be detrimental to photodegradation of target organics. The higher RH might lead to competitive adsorption between H2O and HCHO on the surface of the photocatalyst. Additionally, excess water might provide recombination centres for electron–hole pairs, which would result in a lower photocatalytic activity. Therefore, the removal of HCHO decreased with increasing RH in the higher range [17,18]. It was found that a RH of 50±5% was the optimal level for the removal of HCHO in the gas phase. 4 Conclusion The effectiveness of formaldehyde gas degradation by photocatalysis with energy-saving lamp is presented in this study. The results of this work are summarised as follows: 1. The relatively high photocatalytic activity of Zr x Ti1−x O2 powder with an energy-saving lamp was attributed a better photo-generated electron transfer, enough hydroxyl groups on high surface area samples and visible light-induced degradation. The Zr0.08Ti0.92O2 catalyst with the highest activity showed at least 92% formaldehyde conversion at 48h. Meanwhile, the kinetic model of the PCO process would follow the Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic model. 2. Higher RH might led to competitive adsorption between H2O and HCHO on the photocatalyst surface. Additionally, excess water might provide recombination centres for electron–hole pairs. Therefore, high levels of humidity suppress activity. coredata.dc:description: TiO2, a widely used, inexpensive white powder, has been considered the most promising photocatalyst for the degradation of formaldehyde in air. However, the application of TiO2 without other metal and nonmetal doping is limited because it requires UV activation with a high-energy band gap, and <5% of the solar radiation reaching the earth's surface can be used. To improve the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, sol–gel nano TiO2 with Zr doping can be activated by the UV–vis radiation available in sunlight to perform solar photocatalysis. The properties of the Zr x Ti1−x O2 catalysts were fully characterised by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). Our results demonstrate that the optical response of TiO2 was shifted from UV to the visible light region with the introduction of zirconium. The photocatalytic tests indicated that the Zr x Ti1−x O2 catalyst demonstrated higher activity for the degradation of formaldehyde compared with P25 and TiO2 under UV–vis light irradiation with an energy-saving lamp.
coredata.dc:title: Photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous HCHO by Zr x Ti1−x O2 catalysts under UV–vis light irradiation with an energy-saving lamp
